WRITING.TITLE: Getting Help?
WRITING.TEXT: Posted this on another Reddit for self harm but thought I might as well cover all the bases XD. So I've had a problem with self harm for a long time but after high school and into community college I was self harm free. 2 years under my belt and then the first semester of a 4 year college experience and I slip. It wasn't anything big or bad at first but its escalated with me being stuck at home alone, nothing quite that deep but I am littered with bruises and cuts all over my body. I even found myself tracing back over the carved "freak" on my thigh from years ago. I've been wanting to cut deeper or break a bone and that's terrifying to me. So I took the first step and got myself a psychiatrist but they seem laissez faire about it all, like since I haven't acted on cutting deeper (though still leaving visible scaring) and because my suicidal thoughts are more passive than active they're just wanting to handle it with monthly meetings. I'm not sure that will be beneficial to me as my behavior has become such a habit/addiction that isn't being interrupted and therefore any handling of my thoughts or feelings come after the harm not before. I know a lot of people don't like inpatient care but I think that would be the best thing for me at this point--active forced discussion and intervention--but I'm feeling kind of iffy about asking for it. I'm not sure if its the psychiatrist's words getting to me or not but I keep feeling like I don't actually deserve inpatient care because I'm not "bad" enough (which of course is triggering me into getting worse). I would love to hear y'all's thoughts on this: Has anyone had inpatient care without extremely deep scars? How was that experience? Should I try more appointments with my psychiatrist before making a final decision on this or go with my intuition? I think I'm just looking for some helpful outlooks and supportive messages. Love this community and happy to finally join for real! \-Thanks!

Not really on par with all the other suggestions (I agree with Ticket to Ride if you want more of a traditional board game) but my main go to for middle school aged kids and family fun is Munchkin. Its easy to pick up, easy to set up, competitive without being too competitive and it comes in completely playable by themselves packs themed around kids and adults favorite cartoons. Playing with my TMNT or Oz munchkin decks with kids at summer camp quickly became their favorite part of the day while also being a great stress reliever for me. Villainous is a bit more difficult to explain game play wise because every villain has their own win condition but it's another that's pretty fun with a tween/teen audience. It's Disney themed with the win conditions and cards themed around the villains and their motivations in the movies. A bit more strategy based but with 6 different villains in the main pack for everyone to try out (as well as replaying the same villain after gaining a better understanding of their strategy) it's great for repeat play.

I know this is a super old post (was going through all time rated) but I thought I'd give a little exercise tip as it sounds like running isn't working for you. So I have severe social anxiety--enough so that even exercising at home alone gives me anxiety as if like what I'm in the Truman Show--it's horrid. So for the longest time I had trouble losing the weight I've put on during my depression episodes. One thing that helped a lot was essentially tricking myself into daily mile long walks. I've found that when I rant to myself about something or when I listen to a podcast that is thought provoking I pace. Pacing around my house for an hour is equal to a mile long walk. It's a great simple exercise without feeling like one and as it allows me to rant to myself about my day it's fairly cathartic and helps reduce the anxiety I feel late at night in bed. I lost 10lbs in under a month just walking. You can also change it up by walking up stairs or with groceries in your arms (because the whole thing for it to work is to trick yourself that you aren't exercising). You might not need to trick yourself if that doesn't make you anxious but it really helped me feel better about my body even when I was bigger.

Hello! I'm so sorry you have to deal with all of this. It just sounds like all this bad stuff is stacking up on you. I think it's quite amazing that you can speak/understand 4 languages! I also agree that it is beneficial in many ways and can see why your mom taught you in this way. That all being said I 100% get the feeling of that many languages being a hindrance to your mental health and understanding of the world around you. Words/phrases can have extremely different meanings across different languages and having that many languages to pull from in your head means listening, speaking, reading, or any kind of processing takes more time and effort than it does for others. And a lot of the time other people don't care to wait for you. As for your mental health, don't be afraid to self diagnosis. It won't get you any medicine but there are many tips, tricks, communities, and therapies that you can do/participate in at home that can greatly improve your mental health. For example, I'm fairly sure I have ADHD but the going to the doctor for a diagnosis for it terrifies me so instead I incorporate ADHD strategies into my everyday. This has helped me handle those symptoms as well as just made me feel better in a little way. And if possible maybe look through other people's posts on their mental health and find ones similar to how your feeling, showing people those might be easier for them to understand than you trying to explain on your own (although having to do this kinda sucks on your end). As someone who struggles with self harming behavior I completely understand how it helps when you feel bad. I'm sorry you feel like you have to resort to that to feel better. Next, you are NOT a freak for not having sexual attraction or for wanting to kiss a girl. You are completely valid and I wholeheartedly agree that you shouldn't have to kiss someone for others to treat you with respect. Keep on living whether that be for your mom or your neighbor. Keep on and hopefully soon you'll feel a bit better. I hope you find some people who understand you. Stay safe.

This is what I got from my therapist as well. They are not qualified to diagnose you and generally are just there to talk to you about things. That being said some of those mental illnesses you described don't get much help from knowing the underlying causes. Depression is a big one that is helped by this but I never felt knowing where my anxiety stems from helps me in those situations. I'd suggest dropping the therapist and picking up a psychologist instead. Psychiatrists can diagnosis you but that's really all they are there for, psychologists from my experience work with me to create methods for handling my illnesses and help me by challenging my self-talk.

I think I'm leaning towards ESH for the argument. First thing first the game thing was kinda shitty you're definitely the asshole there. Moving things around in the inventory or making phallic structures are funny because at their core they're just trivial pranks. Doing those things is an inconvenience at most and easy to laugh about as they're easy to fix or ignore. Changing the difficulty of the boss without notification is completely different as it changes elements that aren't easy to respond to and makes the "prank" feel less of a funny inconvenience and more like malicious intent. But that's a separate issue. The issue here is the argument and that's why I lean towards ESH. If you talked about it with your friend and reached an understanding then that should have been it. No one should be able to bring up prior grievances if they were already settled. Your friends an asshole for ranting about something you thought wasn't an issue anymore. That being said you are an asshole for the way you snapped. I don't necessarily blame you for getting angry about the situation being brought up again but you just flipped the script and did the exact same thing by bringing up his past mental breakdowns and venting and I guess also just being his friend? Did he even know those were issues you had or had those things been settled in the past as well and you found fit to bring them up so you could have a bigger high horse? It just feels very hypocritical. Add on to that that you guilted him by bringing up your dying family member situation as if that stops someone from being shitty or absolves the problem any because you're dealing with bigger things is really gaslighty. I just think the situation could have been handled better. Honestly best advice here is to take a step back, introspect before snapping and recognize that you're too stressed to handle a conversation like this civilly. Straight up say "You know I'm dealing with a lot right now with the situation with my family member and want to just play this game as an escape. I'd love to talk about this issue with you later but at this time i don't think I could have this discussion without it being blown out of proportion". If they don't accept that kind of response they're not a great or understanding friend in the first place.

YTA. Portions may be the recommended amount but often times they are a joke. They like many other things they don't take into account different metabolisms and lifestyles. I tend to eat super small portions because I talk throughout meals and feel full faster, I make up for those missed calories through interment snacking. People telling me I don't know what I need or putting more on my plate is rude as hell and not appreciated. Honestly her weight shouldn't be your problem. It's not your responsibility to police her eating habits and honestly doing so will cause a rift between you. If you're really worried about her weight and want to make an effort to help donso in a way that's not rude as hell. Start including her into quality time that forces exercise like walking with you or playing interactive games or something similar. If she's a picky eater the way to help isn't probably through food.
Then it's obviously not a problem for her. Worrying about it is more damaging to your health than hers. Just let her be and she'll live with the consequences and you can continue on with your life.

Gonna be the unpopular opinion on this one and say YWBTA. Your dad sucks full stop but you also have to understand that your brothers relationship with him is not the same as yours. You're essentially taking away something of great importance from him that you yourself have claimed isn't necessary to do. Living from paycheck to paycheck sucks, I'm currently doing it so I completely understand the want to not have to struggle, but taking away the car from your brother seems like trying to erase your father from his life. You have to accept that his relationship with his dad is different and getting rid of the only heirloom he has from him (whether it's extremely dipped in misogyny or not) is in fact bad. When he gets older and maybe understands more about what you had to experience maybe he'll feel differently but currently doing this is going to hurt. If I were him this would greatly change my relationship with you guys and it might make him more believing of his dad's take on the situation/his dad's ideals than yours. If it could be explained how much the money would help in a way he understands maybe he'll feel better about it being sold. But at the center of it, you're taking away something from him he already thinks of as his personal possession as well as a very important aspect of his relationship/memory with his father and it's kind of a betrayal when taken that way.

But you also aren't considering the ramifications. Poor families are more susceptible to dying from this pandemic than others do to problems with medical costs and availability. Sending many of these kids back to school WILL be a death sentence for them, their parents, and anyone else living with them ESPECIALLY those families made of POC and those who struggle financially. Every situation is going to be a trolley problem but I think I'll chose the option where we don't deliberately send a ton of families and children to their deaths.

Words of oppression are often times taken back by those being opressed and made into part of their shared identity. In high school I used to not be able to do it without crying in front of everyone. College really helped me deal with situations like those. I still get really anxious beforehand with vomiting and diarrhea and tears and all that trash but once the actual situation starts I'm able to get through it and then afterwards I can panic. It's like I go into that fight mode of adrenaline during the speech and I just power through. The only bad thing is it really takes a lot out of me like the day after a speech I can't have any social interaction without panicking. Y'all pool fences! No kid should be riding around a pool in the first place. Not blaming the hotel for not having one of course this is on the parents but come on, pool edges are not places for activity.

This is understandable true. But residential pools should be fenced in. It's like making child safe decisions in your house, a defense measure that hopefully won't be needed but should be installed anyway. This is why I stated that I didn't blame the hotel because hotels shouldn't be responsible for parents not looking after their kids in this kind of situation but think of an at home situation. A lot of people have pools in their backyards not fenced in and yet kids play around those pools, covered or not that's a real safety issue and parents aren't as diligent as they'd like to think they are. If you're able to afford the kids and the pool you should be able to afford the safety needed. Besides knowing how to swim does not stop drowning from occurring. Say the kid hit their head going down from falling off their scooter and passes out, knowing how to swim wouldn't help in that situation but a fence installed would have prevented that from occuring. What if they have a medical situation and are unable to get out or use their arms or legs? What if they get tangeled in something like a pool cover or something they were playing with like a jump rope? Or what if they know how and still drown! More than half of drowning cases are of people who know how to swim anyhow. It's just a safety thing. And keep in mind this is a pool not a lake or canal (no one is saying everything has to be fenced in) it's also one that has kids playing around it. Does your country not put up a fence on the side of the playground nearest to the road so kids don't walk into traffic? Because it's the exact same idea. Again I don't think the hotel is at fault as the kids shouldn't have been allowed to play around the pool but in a residential or play area fences should be expected (also they're not that expensive to set up).

Most hotels don't have pool fences because they already have a restricted pool only area which is either sectioned off or in its own room. It's the parents faults here because it looks like they just let their kids play in the restricted area.

Here's some advice that has helped me (someone who gets panic attacks and sobs every time I drive because my social anxiety acts up). I don't yet have my license because I can never work up the nerve to take it (direct social interaction AND driving? my worst nightmare) but I drive a lot with my permit because of my dad's hospital visits. YOU and YOUR comfort is the MOST important aspect as long as it's safe. That means if you want to wait until you get a light to turn right do so no matter if people honk or are irritated. If parallel parking freaks you out you never have to do it again, go ahead and pay for parking garages and things and you'll feel better. If parking makes you anxious go ahead and pull through or park away from people. If you don't really know who should be going at a four way stop go ahead and wave some people on until you're comfortable. And I know it makes you an asshole to other drivers but if you truly are having trouble seeing go ahead and put your brights on, they're there to help. The test is aptitude not a representation of how you have to drive. Once you get through that you can avoid all the situations that make you uncomfortable as possible and you'll automatically feel better about driving.

Special interests tend to be more personal in my experience. Like it's something that causes extreme feelings of happiness and enthusiasm and also is deeply emotional. Like if someone insulted a special interest that would feel as if they were insulting you because it's that special to you. They also last a long time. Hyperfixations tend to be more interest based in that they are attention focused and less emotional. It does tend to be something that comes and goes and can also be something you don't even enjoy. You can hyperfixate on cleaning even if you hate cleaning. Hyperfixations can also go hand in hand with special interests with you hyperfixating on specific elements of the interest. So for me (for example) TMNT is a special interest. I get very emotional over opinions on it and can talk for days about the topic. It's also an interest that hasn't gone away in 22 years. But a few years ago I was obsessed with this one specific villain from TMNT and I researched and drew them all the time. That obsession has passed (I still like them) but the special interest still remains. This is at least my take on it. It'll be interesting how everyone describes this!

Bruises are not parallel and don't normally appear on meaty parts of the body. Ah yes my time has come. I actually am really drawn to April owning her grandfather's or father's antique shop. I think it just has many an opportunity for story lines from things found in the shop to the shop itself that I'm really quite disappointed more TMNT iterations don't play with it. April also should be an adult. I HATE aging down characters for better representation or to make them more relatable. If you want a female teen character make a new one and older women are as relatable as teens even more so sometimes. I love adult April because then you get mother figure or only female figure in their life story lines and I think those are super important. I like Casey having some sort of beef with the Purple Dragons. I think the gang drama works much better to be his focus with the turtles helping than the other way around. Love Mikey and Don's relationship in the 1990 movie. Perfect middle sibling energy. Honestly a lot of Raph and Leo fighting moments just make me roll my eyes. They never seem to have a real reason behind the argument other than Raph doesn't like Leo being the leader because?????? like the beef most of the time isn't explained. I get the 2007 movie version because Leo stayed away and left them but most of the time I'm just bored of it. Let other brother relationships shine (Raph and Don please or Don and Mikey, heck give me more individual son moments with Splinter!). I do like the idea though of Raph being the eldest and Leo being next in line but being chosen as the leader. It gives a real reason for the arguments and resentment and also opens up the possibility for both of them to learn more about each other and grow (but this will probably just stay a fantasy). I hate mutations. Like 2012 is horrid because almost every character gets mutated by the end! There is no reason for this. It's actually a much more interesting story if the turtles main enemies and conflicts come from humans and humanity issues rather than mutants. I think it opens up the door to better exploration of their feelings of being outcasts stuck with only each other for most of their lives. Like give me characters like Bishop! Um other ones are I like the turtles to be older teens rather than younger. Like 18 for most of them with the youngest being 16. Also while I want them to be goofy and teenagers, they aren't children, they've dealt with being hidden and hunted for all of their lives so I like when they are more mature than you'd think for the age. Donnie is smart and a genius in engineering but hes not a stuck up know it all nor an expert in every science to exist. He builds things he doesn't create new elements. I like black April! I'm a fan of classic origin story for the turtles too.

WRITING.TITLE: Inpatient Care Whilst in College...?
WRITING.TEXT: This is a long winded explanation of a situation so for some here's this: TL;DR: I'm experiencing what I think is psychosis and wondering if inpatient is a good option and if it is how do I go about getting there. So to start off my mental situation has gotten worse. A lot worse let's say. I am completely covered in 2nd degree and first degree burns and cuts from self harm at this point. Nothing too deep cut wise but just littered in them from feet to chest. The only place I haven't done is my neck and face though I think about it daily. For the first time in a long time I self harmed on campus. I monitor for the wood studio on campus and I constantly walked around this last Sunday looking for tools to hurt myself. I even tried to burn myself while making food today! I can't get myself to do anything at all so I'm falling behind in my classes and yet can't bring myself to really care. I have a breakdown (vomiting and panicking and passing out) thinking about going to most of my classes and I'm honestly thinking about skipping them this week so as not to throw up again. My problems with hygiene and hunger have gotten worse and I've started having actual real thoughts about slitting my throat (not that I'd actually do it because death causes me too much anxiety). So yeah, bad. And being home isn't making it better. My dad is undergoing treatment for cancer so my mother and her mother have come to stay to help out and get the house ready for moving. This means that 2 people who outrageously stress me out and make me feel lesser are making my safe place not safe as well as having everything around me changing so much I just don't know how to handle it. I'm self harming, disassociating, crying, and freaking out at least once a day so much so I feel like I'm falling into psychosis. I think I need help. Currently I see a psychiatrist (2 visits over 3 months with her and I don't think we really click) with my next meeting with her this upcoming Monday. She knows I self harm and worries about it enough she gave me her cell to call if I felt like I needed more help(which makes me anxious to think to do). She also knows I've been having a tough time at it but most of everything going on now has been a new or escalated development since our last meeting so she's a bit out of the loop for my current mental state. I was thinking about doing an inpatient stay. To one forcibly get out of this situation and have some time to learn to handle everything going on and two get more consistent reoccurring help for a while. I'm not even on any medications or therapies for everything that's happening. The problem is I don't know if this is the right response? Like, I don't really think I'm a threat to myself I don't really think I'll try to commit suicide so should I even go? And if I do how do I go about it? Should I call/text her what's happening now or should I wait till my appointment Monday to talk to her? How would this all effect my classes? Will this count against me? I just feel like I'm at rock bottom and digging myself even further the long I go. Just need some thoughts on what I should do. Thoughts encouragements, experiences, and ideas very very welcome. Thanks! (Just read the rules, I'm from the US Midwest)

This is a classic example of people not understanding the difference between a fear and a phobia. I'm afraid of or have a FEAR of most spiders. I find their movement very unsettling and would rather not see one. If I do see one though I can take action by killing it or catching it and letting it out or ignoring it until I can't see it anymore. I can hold and pet a tarantula fine. I have a PHOBIA of moths. I pass out if one touches me. I avoid lights at night and won't leave my porch light on for the same reason. I'll walk home in the dark. I get very panicky when I see one, have extreme panic attacks when near one or when one is trapped in a space with me. I'll avoid whole rooms if I saw a moth in there and won't enter them no matter what if I haven't seen evidence it's been caught or killed. I'll then be unsettled and jumpy for days afterwards from the experience. It's a phobia, it comes intense reactions to the stimulus that I can't control. Phobias are not jokes and shouldn't be taken lightly but sadly most people don't seem to understand that. NTA OP. You don't want to be attached to someone who would weaponize your phobia as the other redditor rightly pointed out.

I agree with the other redditor. It's about understanding and respecting a culture and their practices or not doing so. A good example of cultural appropriation is headdresses and how in plains Indian culture it's a highly respected item that is earned by someone that earned a place of respect but how many people wear them as a fashion statement or as generic "Indian" outfits. That's wrong because not only are you generalizing tons of culturally different tribes into this carivurture amalgamation of their cultures but you are also degrading the meaning surrounding the article. For me cultural appropriation is easy to spot if it's: 1. something that is still negatively affecting the community (an example of this is how black hairstyles are a fashion trend for white people and yet when black people wear them they are discriminated against) 2. something that was harmed or shamed by colonists (Polynesian tattoo artists were tortured and killed over their tattooing by westerners and many elements from their cultural history are gone due to this so getting a Polynesian tattoo now without proper understanding or acceptance of the symbolism and culture behind it is actively playing into the erasure of their culture and putting you on pare with those of the past) 3. or if the borrowed aspect of the culture is used in a way to perpetuate a stereotype of said culture (an example of this is "war paint" of handprints on the face and then acting out of control and blood thirsty) Generally anything done without real knowledge of all the important bits. This is dressing up in sugar skulls without knowing what sugar skulls are created. It's hard to differentiate sometimes but I think I've mostly got it.
